Vulnerabilities: SQL injection in Tenant and Management login pages
Flawed validation allowing upload of PHP webshell

Steps.Description: Exploit SQL injection vulnerability to dump users table.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker aims to extract information from the database by exploiting the SQL injection vulnerability.
StepDetails.Action: Using SQLMap, the attacker dumps the users table in the database.
StepDetails.Result: The users table containing sensitive information (id, name, role, password, username) is successfully dumped.

Steps.Description: Exploit flawed image upload validation to upload a PHP webshell.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker wants to upload a PHP webshell to gain remote access to the system.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker crafts a request with a file named 'pwned.jpg.php' and uploads it using the flawed image upload validation.
StepDetails.Result: The PHP webshell is successfully uploaded and can be accessed at http://10.8.201.87/HTXIC/vendor/images/.

Steps.Description: Gain remote access to the system using the PHP reverse shell payload.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker aims to establish a remote shell on the target system.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker executes a PHP reverse shell payload to establish a bash shell on the system.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker successfully gains a bash shell on the system.

Steps.Description: Escalate privileges by exploiting the SUID bit on the systemctl binary.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker wants to escalate their privileges to root on the system.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker creates a service using the systemctl binary with the SUID bit set.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker successfully escalates their privileges to root on the system.
